page.title: 11Housing in Caerhun Parish
page.content: There are few new houses, most being traditional country dwellings built of rubble and stone - 'tyddyn' or farm, 'bwthyn' or cottage, 'hafodty' or summerhouse - which blend into the landscape. Bryniau and Tyddyn-y-coed are 17th century examples. Caecoch, at 1260 feet, is said to be the highest occupied cottage in North Wales. Most homes are owner-occupied. Many have mains water but householders are res- ponsible for their own septic tanks. Modernisations, e.g. extensions, damp- proofing, double-glazing, insulation and well-planned kitchens transform old houses into attractive homes with fine views. Some farmhouses are sold separately when farms become vacant. Most homes have well-kept gardens and small orchards. Pride is taken in possession of Welsh dressers, chests, clocks and the 'Cwpwrdd tridarn'.
